thread.title: Cubs, Arrietta blank Bucs to advance
thread.title_full: Cubs, Arrietta blank Bucs to advance

title: Cubs, Arrietta blank Bucs to advance
text:
Cubs, Arrietta blank Bucs to advance Cubs, Arrietta blank Bucs to advance 
The Chicago Cubs' Dexter Fowler (24) celebrates after hitting a home run during the fifth inning against the Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League Wild Card Game at PNC Park in Pittsburgh on Wednesday. (Nuccio DiNuzzo/Chicago Tribune/TNS) Cubs, Arrietta blank Bucs to advance Buy Photo 
The Chicago Cubs' Dexter Fowler (24) celebrates with teammates after hitting a home run in the fifth inning in the National League Wild Card Game at PNC Park in Pittsburgh on Wednesday. (Nuccio DiNuzzo/Chicago Tribune/TNS) 
PITTSBURGH — Jake Arrieta pitched the Cubs to their first postseason victory in 12 years Wednesday night, a 4-0 shutout of the Pirates in the National League wild-card game at PNC Park. The Cubs advance to the best-of-five NLDS to face the Cardinals, starting Friday in St. Louis. 
Arrieta, who had three shutouts in the regular season, allowed four hits and struck out 11. With the bases loaded in the sixth, he prompted Starling Marte to ground into a double play to end the inning and also benefited from a double play to end the seventh. 
Rookie Kyle Schwarber drove in the Cubs’ first three runs, including a two-run homer off Pirates right-hander Gerrit Cole in the third inning. Schwarber’s single to left field in the first inning drove in Dexter Fowler for an early 1-0 lead. 
Fowler was 3-for-4 with three runs scored and a fifth-inning solo homer off Cole, who pitched five innings. 
The benches cleared in the seventh inning when Pirates reliever Tony Watson hit Arrieta with a pitch on the hip. Arrieta had hit a Pirates player with a pitch in the fifth and sixth innings. The Pirates’ Sean Rodriguez was ejected following the altercation, which didn’t appear to escalate much beyond pushing and yelling.
